properties.areaDesc: Branch; St. Joseph; Hillsdale; Steuben; La Porte; Berrien; Cass; Lagrange; Elkhart; St. Joseph
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued April 13 at 3:40PM EDT by NWS Northern Indiana
properties.description:
A strong low pressure system is expected to impact the region
from tonight through early Sunday morning. As temperatures drop
into the mid 30s overnight, snow is expected to mix with rain for
locations along and north of route 6. Snow accumulations of 1 to
2 inches are possible primarily on grassy areas and elevated,
cooler surfaces. Given that overnight low temperatures will remain
above freezing, no accumulation is expected on roadways. Motorist
should slow down if traveling overnight as roads will be wet.

NWSheadline: Strong Storm System To Bring Late Season Snow Overnight

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued April 13 at 2:38PM CDT until April 16 at 7:34AM CDT by NWS Norman OK
properties.description:
The Flood Warning continues for
The Deep Red Creek near Randlett.

* from Sunday afternoon to Tuesday morning...or until the warning is
cancelled.

* At  1:30 PM Saturday the stage was 3.0 feet.

* Minor flooding is forecast.

* Flood stage is 20.0 feet.

* Forecast...The Deep Red Creek will rise above flood stage late
Sunday afternoon and crest near 22.3 feet mid Monday morning. The
Deep Red Creek will fall below flood stage early Tuesday morning.

* Impact...At 22.0 feet...Flood depths up to 2 feet occur over
croplands...pastures...and low-lying local roads along and near
the creek.

properties.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued April 13 at 3:38PM EDT until April 13 at 3:45PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
properties.description:
Flood waters have receded around Kannapolis and Concord, however
streamlevels remain high and downstream rises are ongoing along
the Rocky River watershed.  Therefore the Flash Flood Warning
will be replaced with a Flood Advisory.  Please continue to
heed all road closures to give time to allow crews to assess
road stability for your safety.

NWSheadline: THE FLASH FLOOD WARNING FOR NORTHWESTERN CABARRUS COUNTY WILL EXPIRE AT 345 PM EDT

properties.description:

The Beaver Creek near Electra.

* from Sunday morning to Monday evening...or until the warning is
cancelled.

* At  2:00 PM Saturday the stage was 11.4 feet.

* Moderate flooding is forecast.

* Flood stage is 24.0 feet.

* Forecast...The Beaver Creek will rise above flood stage mid Sunday
morning and crest near 27.6 feet Sunday evening. The Beaver Creek
will fall below flood stage late Monday afternoon.

* Impact...At 28.0 feet...Widespread flood levels up to 4 feet in
depth cover farm and range lands...and may inundate some oil and
gas facilities...along and near the creek in southern Wilbarger
County and southwestern Wichita County.

properties.areaDesc: Shelby, TX; Nacogdoches, TX; San Augustine, TX
properties.headline: Tornado Warning issued April 13 at 2:37PM CDT until April 13 at 3:00PM CDT by NWS Shreveport LA
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Shreveport has issued a

* Tornado Warning for...
East central Nacogdoches County in eastern Texas...
Southwestern Shelby County in eastern Texas...
Northwestern San Augustine County in eastern Texas...

* Until 300 PM CDT.

* At 237 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located near Melrose, or 15 miles east of Nacogdoches, moving
northeast at 30 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed.
Damage to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree
damage is likely.

* This tornadic thunderstorm will remain over mainly rural areas of
east central Nacogdoches, southwestern Shelby and northwestern San
Augustine Counties, including the following locations... Chireno.
properties.instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

CMAMtext: Tornado Warning in this area til 3:00 PM CDT. Take shelter now. Check local media. -NWS

East central Burke County in western North Carolina...

* Until 415 PM EDT.

* At 336 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located 9 miles east of Morganton, or over Rutherford College,
moving east at 20 mph.

HAZARD...Tornado and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed.
Damage to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree
damage is likely.

* This dangerous storm will be near...
Connelly Springs around 340 PM EDT.
Icard, Rhodhiss, Hildebran, Granite Falls and Sawmills around 350
PM EDT.
Longview, Hickory Regional Airport and Mountain View around 400 PM
EDT.
Hickory, Newton, St. Stephens, Bethlehem and Lake Hickory around

Other locations impacted by this dangerous thunderstorm include
Northlakes.
properties.instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

Please report damaging winds, hail, or flooding to the National
Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800,
2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, or by posting on our Facebook page, or Tweet it using
hashtag nwsgsp. Your message should describe the event and the
specific location where it occurred.

CMAMtext: Tornado Warning in this area til 4:15 PM EDT. Take shelter now. Check local media. -NWS

* WINDS...Southerly wind gusts of 30 to 40 mph.

properties.areaDesc: Windsor; Northern Franklin; Western Essex; Eastern Clinton; Eastern Chittenden; Eastern Essex; Western Franklin; Western Clinton; Southern Franklin; Eastern Franklin; Northern St. Lawrence; Orleans; Washington; Orange; Eastern Rutland; Lamoille; Eastern Addison; Caledonia; Southwestern St. Lawrence; Southeastern St. Lawrence; Western Addison; Western Chittenden; Western Rutland; Essex
properties.headline: Flood Watch issued April 13 at 3:36PM EDT until April 16 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Burlington VT
properties.description:
The Flood Watch continues for

* Portions of northern New York and Vermont, including the
following areas, in northern New York, Eastern Clinton,
Eastern Essex, Northern Franklin, Northern St. Lawrence,
Southeastern St. Lawrence, Southern Franklin, Southwestern St.
Lawrence, Western Clinton, and Western Essex. In Vermont,
Caledonia, Eastern Addison, Eastern Chittenden, Eastern
Franklin, Eastern Rutland, Essex, Lamoille, Orange, Orleans,
Washington, Western Addison, Western Chittenden, Western
Franklin, Western Rutland, and Windsor.

* From Sunday evening through Tuesday morning

* A moisture-laden frontal system will bring widespread rainfall
Sunday afternoon through Monday morning, with rainfall amounts
from 0.75 to 1.25 inches expected. This will combine with
increasing snow melt due to warm temperatures through Sunday
morning to produce significant runoff into area rivers and
streams. Main stem rivers most at risk for minor category
flooding include the Ausable, Missisquoi, Passumpsic, Otter
Creek, Winooski, Lamoille, and possibly the Mad river. Sharp
river rises are likely beginning Sunday night. Most main stem
rivers are expected to crest during the day Monday based on
current indications.

* Those with interests in low-lying or flood prone areas should
continue to monitor the latest forecasts over the weekend and
into Monday.
properties.instruction:
A Flood Watch means there is a potential for flooding based on
current forecasts.

You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible
Flood Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be
prepared to take action should flooding develop.

NWSheadline: FLOOD WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM SUNDAY EVENING THROUGH TUESDAY MORNING

properties.headline: Flood Watch issued April 13 at 3:36PM EDT until April 16 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Gray ME
properties.description:
Very warm temperatures today and rainfall expected Sunday night
through Monday will have the rivers rising over the next few days.
Low pressure will move through central new Hampshire and into
Maine Monday. It is expected that 0.75 to 1 inch of rain will
fall through Tuesday morning. This may lead to minor river
flooding.
The National Weather Service in Gray has issued a

* Flood Watch for portions of Maine and northern New Hampshire,
including the following areas, in Maine, Androscoggin, Central
Somerset, Kennebec, Northern Franklin, Northern Oxford,
Southern Franklin, Southern Oxford, and Southern Somerset. In
northern New Hampshire, Northern Carroll, Northern Coos,
Northern Grafton, Southern Carroll, Southern Coos, and
Southern Grafton.

* From Monday morning through Tuesday morning

* Rainfall and snowmelt may lead to minor river flooding.
properties.instruction:

You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible

prepared to take action should flooding develop.

properties.areaDesc: Croatan and Roanoke Sounds; Alligator River; Albemarle Sound
properties.headline: Small Craft Advisory issued April 13 at 3:34PM EDT until April 15 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
properties.description:
A strong cold front will approach the waters Sunday and push
through early Monday. Strong south to southwest winds 20 to 30
knots will develop. Gale force winds are likely to develop south
of Oregon Inlet Sunday night and continue through mid day Monday.
Seas will peak at 6-12 ft Monday. Winds and seas will be slowly to
subside late Monday and Monday night.
The National Weather Service in Newport/Morehead City has issued
a Small Craft Advisory, which is in effect from 11 PM Sunday to
8 PM EDT Monday.

* WINDS...Southwest 20 to 25 kt with gusts up to 30 kt.

* WAVES...2 to 3 feet.
properties.instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots
and/or seas of 6 feet or greater are expected to produce
hazardous wave conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners,
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

NWSheadline: SMALL CRAFT ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 11 PM SUNDAY TO 8 PM EDT MONDAY

* TIMING...7 PM CDT this evening until 1 AM CDT Sunday.

* IMPACTS...Loose objects left outdoors will likely be blown
around. High profile vehicles may experience difficult driving
conditions.
properties.instruction:

are expected. Winds this strong can make driving difficult,
especially for high profile vehicles. Use extra caution.

properties.headline: Tornado Warning issued April 13 at 2:33PM CDT until April 13 at 3:00PM CDT by NWS Shreveport LA
properties.description:
At 232 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located 10 miles southeast of Jonesboro, moving northeast at 45
mph.

HAZARD...Tornado and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

Locations impacted include...
Brownsville-Bawcomville, Chatham, Fondale, Vixen, Bosco, Luna and
Lapine.
properties.instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

properties.headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued April 13 at 3:32PM EDT until April 13 at 3:45PM EDT by NWS Raleigh NC
properties.description:
At 332 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located over Pinehurst, or
near Southern Pines, moving east at 25 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage to
roofs, siding, and trees.

Locations impacted include...
Southern Pines, Pinehurst, Aberdeen, Whispering Pines, Pinebluff,
Foxfire and Taylortown.
properties.instruction:
For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

Straight line winds can blow down trees, power lines, and damage
mobile homes and other buildings. Seek shelter in a sturdy structure
until the storm has passed. Stay away from windows as flying debris
generated by damaging winds can be deadly.

Torrential rainfall is occurring with this storm, and may lead to
flash flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded roadways.

HAZARD...Tornado.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed. Damage
to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree damage is
likely.

This tornadic thunderstorm will remain over mainly rural areas of
north central Rapides Parish.
properties.instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a mobile
home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter and
protect yourself from flying debris.

Heavy rainfall may hide this tornado. Do not wait to see or hear the
tornado. TAKE COVER NOW!

properties.headline: Red Flag Warning issued April 13 at 2:26PM CDT until April 13 at 8:00PM CDT by NWS Austin/San Antonio TX
properties.description:
In the wake of a strong cold front that moved across the area
earlier, strong northwest to north winds behind the front will
lower humidities into the lower 20s while gusting up to 40 MPH at
times. These breezy and dry conditions will result in favorable
conditions for the spread of fires through this evening.
* WINDS...Northwest 20 to 25 mph with gusts up to 40 mph.

* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 19 percent.

* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly.
Outdoor burning is not recommended.
properties.instruction:
A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions
are either occurring now....or will shortly. A combination of
strong winds...low relative humidity...and warm temperatures can
contribute to extreme fire behavior.

properties.description:

* Seas: 4 to 5 feet.
properties.instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots and/or
seas of 5 feet or greater over the coastal waters are expected to
produce hazardous boating conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners...especially those operating smaller
vessels...should avoid navigating in these conditions.

Mariners should pay close attention to the marine forecast...and
consider wind and sea conditions in planning.

properties.headline: Wind Advisory issued April 13 at 3:25PM EDT until April 14 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Jackson KY
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Jackson has issued a Wind
Advisory, which is in effect from 8 AM to 8 PM EDT Sunday.

* TIMING...The strongest winds will develop on the higher terrain
Sunday morning, with the winds developing across all other
locations by midday. The strong winds will continue through
early Sunday evening.

* WINDS...South winds of 15 to 25 mph with gusts to around 40 mph
are expected. A few wind gusts up to 50 mph are possible above
2500 feet.

* IMPACTS...Tree limbs and branches may fall and some weakened
trees may be uprooted, leading to possible power outages.
Driving will be difficult for high profile vehicles on east-
west roads.
properties.instruction:
A Wind Advisory means that winds of 30 to 39 mph and/or gusts of
40 to 57 mph are expected, or are occurring. Winds this strong
can make driving difficult, especially for high profile vehicles.
Use extra caution.

NWSheadline: WIND ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 8 AM TO 8 PM EDT SUNDAY

properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued April 13 at 9:24AM HST until April 13 at 12:45PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Honolulu has extended the

* Flood advisory for...
The island of Hawaii in Hawaii County

* Until 1245 PM HST.

* At 921 AM HST, radar indicated heavy rain along windward Big
Island from Laupahoehoe to Hilo to Pahoa. Rain was falling at a
rate of an inch per hour.

* Locations in the advisory include but are not limited to...
Hilo, Hawaiian Acres, Paauilo, Waipio Valley, Glenwood, Pepeekeo,
Keaau, Hawaii Volcanoes National Park and Honokaa.
properties.instruction:
Stay away from streams, drainage ditches and low lying areas prone to
flooding.

Rainfall and runoff will also cause hazardous driving conditions due
to ponding, reduced visibility and poor braking action.

Do not cross fast flowing or rising water in your vehicle, or on
foot. Turn around, don't drown.

properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued April 13 at 3:24PM EDT by NWS Louisville KY
properties.description:
A low pressure system will move from southern Indiana into central
Ohio Sunday afternoon. As it does so, the change in pressure over
parts of central Kentucky will be fast enough to allow for strong
gusty winds. Areas east of I-65 could see gusts to near 40 mph
during the afternoon hours. A Wind Advisory may eventually be
needed for this time frame.

Tree limbs and branches may fall and some weakened trees may be
uprooted, leading to possible power outages.

NWSheadline: Gusty Winds Expected Sunday Afternoon

cause primarily travel difficulties. Expect snow covered roads
and limited visibilities, and use caution while driving.

properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued April 13 at 3:18PM EDT by NWS Morristown TN
properties.description:
A strong storm system will move across the Tennessee Valley and
southern Appalachians Sunday, producing two rounds of showers and
thunderstorms - one in the morning and one in the late afternoon
and evening. There is an enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms
area wide, with the highest severe threat coming with the late
day storms. The main concern will be damaging winds, but isolated
tornadoes and hail up to quarter size will also be possible.

Windy conditions will develop tonight and Sunday morning.
Southerly winds of 15 to 25 mph with gusts to 45 mph is possible
across most of the area, with gusts up to 60 mph possible in the
mountains.

Please keep abreast of the latest forecast updates from the
National Weather Service.

NWSheadline: An Enhanced Risk of Severe Thunderstorms for Sunday Afternoon and Early Evening across East Tennessee, Southwest Virginia, and Southwest North Carolina

properties.headline: High Wind Warning issued April 13 at 3:17PM EDT until April 14 at 10:00PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
properties.description:
Gusty southerly to southwesterly winds around a strong surface
low associated with large upper storm system will likely affect
higher elevations tonight and most of the day on Sunday.
The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued
a High Wind Warning above 3500 feet, which is in effect from
midnight tonight to 10 PM EDT Sunday.

* LOCATIONS...Higher elevations of the Southern Appalachians of
Western North Carolina and Northeast Georgia.

* HAZARDS...Very windy conditions.

* TIMING...From Midnight tonight to Sunday evening.

* WINDS...South 35 to 45 mph with gusts up to 65 mph.

* IMPACTS...Damaging winds could blow down trees and power
lines. Widespread power outages are possible. Travel could be
difficult, especially for high profile vehicles.
properties.instruction:
A High Wind Warning means a hazardous high wind event is expected
or occurring. Sustained wind speeds of at least 40 mph or gusts
of 58 mph or more can lead to property damage.

Please report damaging winds by calling the National Weather
Service toll free at...1...800...2 6 7...8 1 0 1. Leave a message
with your observation and the specific location where it
occurred. You can also post your report to National Weather
Service Greenville Spartanburg Facebook or tweet your report
using hashtag nwsgsp.

NWSheadline: HIGH WIND WARNING IN EFFECT FROM MIDNIGHT TONIGHT TO 10 PM EDT SUNDAY ABOVE 3500 FEET

properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Shreveport has issued a

* Tornado Warning for...
Northwestern Caldwell Parish in north central Louisiana...
Southeastern Jackson Parish in north central Louisiana...
Southwestern Ouachita Parish in north central Louisiana...
Northern Winn Parish in north central Louisiana...

* Until 300 PM CDT.

* At 215 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a tornado
was located 11 miles south of Jonesboro, moving northeast at 45
mph.

HAZARD...Tornado and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed.
Damage to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree
damage is likely.

* This tornadic thunderstorm will remain over mainly rural areas of
northwestern Caldwell, southeastern Jackson, southwestern Ouachita
and northern Winn Parishes, including the following locations...
Fondale, Sikes, Vixen, Bosco, Hudson, Luna, Chatham, Dodson, Lapine
and Calvin.
properties.instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to a basement or an interior room on the lowest
floor of a sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a
mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter
and protect yourself from flying debris.

CMAMtext: Tornado Warning in this area til 3:00 PM CDT. Take shelter now. Check local media. -NWS

properties.instruction:
A Tornado Watch remains in effect until 700 PM CDT for southeastern
Texas.

For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

If on or near Lake Conroe, get away from the water and move indoors
or inside a vehicle. Remember, lightning can strike out to 15 miles
from the parent thunderstorm. If you can hear thunder, you are close
enough to be struck by lightning. Move to safe shelter now!  Do not
be caught on the water in a thunderstorm.

knots. Seas building to 5 to 7 feet with occasional seas up to 9
feet. Sunday night, Southwest winds 20 to 25 knots becoming west

feet. Monday, West northwest winds 20 to 25 knots becoming
northwest 15 to 20 knots. Seas 5 to 7 feet with occasional seas

6 feet in the afternoon.

are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.

vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

* Flash Flood Warning for...
Alamance County in central North Carolina...
Orange County in central North Carolina...
Durham County in central North Carolina...

* Until 615 PM EDT

* At 259 PM EDT, local law enforcement officials reported flash
flooding occurring. A portion of Johnson Road in Durham County
remains closed due to flooding. Additionally, the Eno River in
Hillsboro has risen above flood stage, with subsequent rises
occurring along the Eno River eastward into Durham County.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Durham, Chapel Hill, Burlington, Graham, Hillsborough, Carrboro,
Mebane, Elon College, Rougemont and Gibsonville.
properties.instruction:
Excessive runoff from the heavy rain will cause flash flooding of
creeks and streams, roads, low lying and poor drainage areas. Do not
drive your vehicle into areas where water covers the road. Many roads
and intersections in the area will quickly flood. When encountering
flooded roads, turn around, don't drown.

properties.headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued April 13 at 3:02PM EDT until April 13 at 3:30PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
properties.description:
At 302 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near Morganton,
moving east at 25 mph.

HAZARD...70 mph wind gusts and ping pong ball size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...People and animals outdoors will be injured. Expect hail
damage to roofs, siding, windows, and vehicles. Expect
considerable tree damage. Wind damage is also likely to
mobile homes, roofs, and outbuildings.

Locations impacted include...
Morganton, Valdese, Gamewell, Cajah's Mountain, Drexel, Connelly
Springs, Rutherford College, Glen Alpine, Lake Rhodhiss and Oak Hill.
properties.instruction:
Remain alert for a possible tornado! Tornadoes can develop quickly
from severe thunderstorms. If you spot a tornado go at once into the
basement or small central room in a sturdy structure.

Large hail can cause major property damage, especially to vehicles.
Strong winds may blow down a few trees and power lines. Seek shelter
inside an interior room.

Please report damaging winds, hail, or flooding to the National
Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800,
2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, or by posting on our Facebook page, or Tweet it using
hashtag nwsgsp. Your message should describe the event and the
specific location where it occurred.

central and southeast Wyoming this afternoon. This activity will
persist for the next several hours. The heaviest showers will be

allow extra time to reach your destination.

properties.description:
At 253 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 11
miles north of Rockingham, moving northeast at 25 mph. A Severe
Thunderstorm Warning may be needed if this storm continues to
strengthen.

Nickel size hail, heavy downpours, and wind gusts of 50 to 55 mph
will be possible with this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Southern Pines, Carthage, Pinehurst, Aberdeen, Whispering Pines,
Pinebluff, Ellerbe, Foxfire, Taylortown and Norman.
properties.instruction:
Seek shelter in a nearby building or vehicle. Wind gusts as high as
50 mph are capable of knocking down small or weakened trees and
blowing around trash cans, potted plants, lawn furniture and other
light outdoor objects.

Locally heavy rain will quickly reduce visibility and result in
ponding of water on roadways, standing water in low lying areas, and
minor flooding of creeks, streams, and areas of poor drainage.
Drivers are urged to slow down and use extra caution to avoid
hydroplaning, especially in urban areas where prolonged heavy rain
can quickly lead to flooding.

properties.headline: Lakeshore Flood Watch issued April 13 at 2:54PM EDT until April 14 at 5:00PM EDT by NWS Cleveland OH
properties.description:
Strong northeast winds will develop Sunday on the lake causing a
seiche to develop. This will result in high water levels on the
western end of Lake Erie. Higher than normal water levels may cause
lakeshore flooding Sunday.
The National Weather Service in Cleveland has issued a Lakeshore
Flood Watch, which is in effect from Sunday morning through
Sunday afternoon.

* LAKE SHORE FLOODING...A northeasterly flow Sunday may cause
higher than normal water levels on the western basin of Lake
Erie. This may result in flooding along the lakeshore. The
combination of rising water levels and waves may result in the
flooding of the lakeshore.

* TIMING...Sunday morning through Sunday afternoon

* IMPACTS...Flooding along the immediate lakeshore and beach and
shoreline erosion may be possible. Rising water levels in
marinas and waterways into the lake could submerge dockage and
shoreline structures.
properties.instruction:
A Lakeshore Flood Watch is issued when conditions are favorable
for lakeshore flooding to develop. Residents on or near the shore
should begin to take action to protect property. Listen for later
statements or warnings.

properties.areaDesc: Lake Huron from Harbor Beach to Port Sanilac 5NM Off Shore to US/Canadian border; Harbor Beach to Port Sanilac MI; Lake Huron from Port Austin to Harbor Beach 5NM Off Shore to the US/Canadian border; Lake Huron from Sturgeon Point to Alabaster MI 5NM off shore to US/Canadian border
properties.headline: Gale Warning issued April 13 at 2:40PM EDT until April 15 at 4:00AM EDT by NWS Detroit/Pontiac MI
properties.description:
A low pressure system remains on track to travel across the Ohio
Valley northeast into New England Sunday into early Monday, which
will bring unsettled weather and lake conditions to start off the
week. As the low pressure system nears the Ohio Valley, the pressure
gradient will strengthen across the open waters and will aid in
quickly ramping up winds speeds and gusts through Sunday morning.
Gusts will peak in excess of 22 knots by late Sunday morning which
will result in the initial issuance of small craft advisories across
Lake Erie, St. Clair, and far southern Lake Huron. Gale warnings to
then go in effect for nearly all of southern and central Lake Huron
and Saginaw Bay by Sunday afternoon as northeasterly gusts continue
to climb to 35 - 40 knots. Long fetch across Lake Huron will also
result in waves to or in excess of 9-10 ft across Lake Huron into
the outer Saginaw Bay. Strong gusts to continue through early Monday
morning before a ridge of high pressure acts to relax the pressure
gradient.
* WIND AND WAVES: During the Gale Warning, expect sustained
winds up to 35 knots from the northeast with gusts up to 40
knots. The largest expected significant waves will be 13 feet
with a potential maximum wave height of 19 feet.

* TIMING: The maximum winds are expected around 8 PM EDT Sunday
with the largest waves expected around 10 PM EDT Sunday.

Refer to the latest marine forecasts for greater detail.
properties.instruction:
A Gale Warning means winds of 34 to 47 knots are imminent or
occuring. Operating a vessel in gale conditions requires
experience and properly equipped vessels. It is highly
recommended that mariners without the proper experience seek safe
harbor prior to the onset of gale conditions.

NWSheadline: GALE WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 2 PM SUNDAY TO 4 AM EDT MONDAY

vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

properties.areaDesc: Outer Saginaw Bay SW of Alabaster to Port Austin MI to Inner Saginaw Bay; Port Austin to Harbor Beach MI; Inner Saginaw Bay SW of Point Au Gres to Bay Port MI
properties.headline: Gale Warning issued April 13 at 2:40PM EDT until April 15 at 4:00AM EDT by NWS Detroit/Pontiac MI
properties.description:
A low pressure system remains on track to travel across the Ohio
Valley northeast into New England Sunday into early Monday, which
will bring unsettled weather and lake conditions to start off the
week. As the low pressure system nears the Ohio Valley, the pressure
gradient will strengthen across the open waters and will aid in
quickly ramping up winds speeds and gusts through Sunday morning.
Gusts will peak in excess of 22 knots by late Sunday morning which
will result in the initial issuance of small craft advisories across
Lake Erie, St. Clair, and far southern Lake Huron. Gale warnings to
then go in effect for nearly all of southern and central Lake Huron
and Saginaw Bay by Sunday afternoon as northeasterly gusts continue
to climb to 35 - 40 knots. Long fetch across Lake Huron will also
result in waves to or in excess of 9-10 ft across Lake Huron into
the outer Saginaw Bay. Strong gusts to continue through early Monday
morning before a ridge of high pressure acts to relax the pressure
gradient.
The National Weather Service in Detroit/Pontiac has cancelled the
Small Craft Advisory.

* WIND AND WAVES: During the Gale Warning, expect sustained
winds up to 35 knots from the northeast with gusts up to 43
knots. The largest expected significant waves will be 13 feet
with a potential maximum wave height of 19 feet.

* TIMING: The maximum winds are expected around 7 PM EDT Sunday
with the largest waves expected around 10 PM EDT Sunday.

Refer to the latest marine forecasts for greater detail.

properties.description:
Sturgeon River near Chassell affecting Houghton County

.An afternoon observation has shown that the river has fallen
below flood stage and is now in action stage prompting the advisory.
The river is expected to continue to fall through the day, however
a warm this week may cause river to rise back into flood stage.
The National Weather Service in Marquette has issued a
* Flood Advisory for
The Sturgeon River near Chassell.
* until Sunday afternoon.
* At 12 PM Saturday the stage was 10.3 feet.
* Bankfull stage is 10.0 feet.
* Flood stage is 10.5 feet.
* At 10.5 feet...The river begins to overflow onto Sturgeon River
Road...Rajala Road...and Aho Road.
properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Residents along these rivers should remain alert and
exercise caution when walking near riverbanks.

A Flood Advisory means minor flooding is possible and rivers are
forecast to exceed bankfull. If you are in the advisory area remain
alert to possible flooding...or the possibility of the advisory being
upgraded to a warning. Report observed flooding to local emergency
services or law enforcement and request they pass this information on
to the National Weather Service.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your favorite media outlet for
further developments and information from the National Weather
Service.

properties.headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued April 13 at 1:11PM CDT until April 13 at 1:45PM CDT by NWS Jackson MS
properties.description:
At 111 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near Goodwill, or 17
miles east of Bastrop, moving northeast at 50 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage to
roofs, siding, and trees.

This severe thunderstorm will remain over mainly rural areas of
southwestern Chicot and southeastern Ashley Counties...northeastern
Morehouse and northwestern West Carroll Parishes, including the
following locations... Bonita.
properties.instruction:
For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

NWSheadline: A SEVERE THUNDERSTORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 145 PM CDT FOR SOUTHWESTERN CHICOT AND SOUTHEASTERN ASHLEY COUNTIES... NORTHEASTERN MOREHOUSE AND NORTHWESTERN WEST CARROLL PARISHES

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued April 13 at 2:11PM EDT until April 14 at 9:30AM EDT by NWS Raleigh NC
properties.description:
Deep River At Moncure affecting Chatham and Lee Counties
The National Weather Service in Raleigh has issued a

* Flood Warning for The Deep River At Moncure.
* from this afternoon to Sunday morning, or until the warning is
cancelled.
* At  1:45 PM Saturday the stage was 8.8 feet.
* Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage by late
this afternoon and continue to rise to near 9.1 feet by this
evening. The river will fall below flood stage by tonight.
* Impact...At 9.0 feet, Flooding is likely upstream of the gage site
along North Plank Road just south of highway 421 in Lee county, and
on R Jordan Road north of highway 421 in Chatham county. At the gage site, flooding reaches the base of the river gage housing, but is confined to woods and pasture immediately adjacent to the river.
properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message. If you encounter deep water while driving, do not
attempt to drive through. Turn around, dont drown.

properties.areaDesc: Vermillion, IN; Warren, IN; Fountain, IN; Parke, IN
properties.headline: Flood Warning issued April 13 at 2:11PM EDT until April 18 at 6:48PM EDT by NWS Indianapolis IN
properties.description:
Wabash River...White River...


.Lowland flooding will develop over the next several days along
portions of the Wabash and White Rivers in western, central, and
southern Indiana as a result of recent and upcoming rainfall.
Near bankfull conditions are expected at Seymour on the East Fork
White River.  Significant flooding is not expected on any of the
rivers.

Rainfall accumulation this past Thursday night and Friday morning at
most Indiana locations was less than half an inch.  A swath of
heavier rain fell across far southwestern, west central, and north
central Indiana, with amounts as high as one and three quarters of an
inch.  The next precipitation event will be showers and thunderstorms
Saturday evening through late Sunday, totaling about one inch to
one and a half inches, locally higher amounts possible.  The majority
of the rain should fall Saturday night.

Flood water is expected to affect local and state roads, agricultural
land, river parks, and river cabins.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Wabash River at Covington.
* from Monday afternoon to Thursday evening.
* At 11:45 AM Saturday the stage was 12.7 feet.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Monday afternoon and continue
to rise to near 18.9 feet by Tuesday afternoon.  It will fall below
flood stage by Thursday morning.
* At 18.0 feet...Five Crossings, a local county river park at old U.S.
Highway 136 bridge site, begins to flood.
properties.instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.

higher ground if threatened by flood waters.

stations, as well as local cable tv outlets for additional
information and possible warnings from the National Weather Service.

properties.areaDesc: Raton Ridge/Johnson Mesa; Southern Sangre de Cristos above 9500 feet; East Slopes Sangre de Cristo Mountains; Northern Sangre de Cristos above 9500 feet/Red River
properties.headline: Winter Storm Warning issued April 13 at 11:52AM MDT until April 13 at 9:00PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
properties.description:
A storm system passing over central and southern New Mexico will
continue to bring accumulating snow to the Sangre de Cristo
Mountains and adjacent highlands through early this evening. Snow
will be light through the morning, but periods of heavy snow will
be possible this afternoon. Visibilities may change quickly. For
the latest New Mexico road conditions visit nmroads.com or call
511.
* WHAT...Heavy snow. Additional snow accumulations of 2 to 5
inches, with locally higher amounts across the southern Sangre
de Cristo Mountains.

* WHERE...East Slopes Sangre de Cristo Mountains, Southern
Sangre de Cristos above 9500 feet, Raton Ridge and Johnson
Mesa and Northern Sangre de Cristos above 9500 feet including
Red River.

* WHEN...Until 9 PM MDT this evening.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Travel could be very difficult,
especially through Raton Pass as well as high mountain passes.
Visibility may be reduced below one half mile at times in
heavy snow and fog. The weight of wet snow on trees and power
lines may lead to local power outages.
properties.instruction:
A Winter Storm Warning for snow means severe winter weather
conditions will make travel very hazardous or impossible. If you
must travel, keep an extra flashlight, food and water in your
vehicle in case of an emergency.

The latest road conditions for New Mexico can be obtained by

properties.areaDesc: Northeast Highlands; West Slopes Sangre de Cristo Mountains; Far Northeast Highlands
properties.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued April 13 at 11:52AM MDT until April 13 at 9:00PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
properties.description:
A storm system passing over central and southern New Mexico will
continue to bring accumulating snow to the Sangre de Cristo
Mountains and adjacent highlands through early this evening. Snow
will be light through the morning, but periods of heavy snow will
be possible this afternoon. Visibilities may change quickly. For
the latest New Mexico road conditions visit nmroads.com or call
511.
* WHAT...Snow. Additional snow accumulations of up to two inches.

* WHERE...Far Northeast Highlands, Northeast Highlands and West
Slopes Sangre de Cristo Mountains.

* WHEN...Until 9 PM MDT this evening.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Plan on slippery road conditions.
Visibility may be reduced below one mile at times in snow and
areas of fog.
properties.instruction:
A Winter Weather Advisory for snow means periods of snow will
cause primarily travel difficulties. Expect snow covered roads
and limited visibilities, and use caution while driving.

The latest road conditions for New Mexico can be obtained by
calling 5 1 1 or 1-800-432-4269.

properties.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued April 13 at 1:41PM EDT until April 13 at 5:30PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
properties.description:
* At 130 PM EDT, emergency management reported a few roadway
flooding issues within the warned area with streams still
rising rapidly.  While heavy rainfall has ended across the
Rock Hill, Fort Mill, and Tega Cay urban areas, additional
flooding issues may occur shortly as significant runoff
continues and streams continue to rise.  It will take some
time for all response to the earlier heavy rainfall to
subside so the Flash Flood Warning will continue.  Drivers
and residents are urged to heed all barricades and seek
higher ground well away from all streams until the threat
has subsided and barricades have been removed.

* The following streamgauge has exceeded Minor Flood Stage:
Big Dutchman Creek 5 NNE Rock Hill.

Current Stage: 12.57 feet and rising rapidly.
Forecast: Big Dutchman Creek will continue to rise past the
Moderate Flood Stage of 13 feet and may reach 14 feet in the
next 60-90 minutes before cresting and beginning to recede.
Action Stage: 8.0 feet.
Minor Flood Stage: 9.0 feet.
Moderate Flood Stage: 13.0 feet.
Impacts: West Oak Dr. and Mt. Gallant Rd. are likely flooded
with significant flooding of adjacent low-lying areas
including the backyards of homes in adjacent subdivisions.
More significant inundation is possible if the stream exceeds
Moderate Flood Stage and some structures may be threatened.
Residents near Big Dutchman Creek must pay close attention
and be prepared to seek higher ground immediately.

* Some locations that may continue to experience flooding
include...Rock Hill, Fort Mill, Tega Cay, Lesslie, Carowinds
and Newport.

* Streams in the warned area are experiencing rapid rises and
flooding of adjacent areas will continue.  Some streams and
associated tributaries include: Manchester Creek, Big Dutchman
Creek, and Wildcat Creek.
properties.instruction:
Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall is causing flooding in urban
areas. Storm drains, streams and other drainages will become
overwhelmed by excessive rainfall, flooding low-lying roads,
intersections, and parking lots. Underpasses are especially dangerous
because sudden flood waters can quickly surround and submerge your
vehicle. Stay alert and avoid flood-prone areas.

When it is safe to do so, please report flood waters or landslides
flowing over roads or threatening property to the National Weather
Service by calling toll free, 1, 800, 2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, by posting on
our Facebook page, or via Twitter using hashtag NWSGSP. Your message
should describe the event and the specific location where it
occurred, including roadways, nearby cross streets, stream names and
other landmarks.

place of safety inside a sturdy structure such as a basement or small
interior room.

hear thunder, you are close enough to be struck by lightning.

properties.headline: Coastal Flood Watch issued April 13 at 1:12PM EDT until April 15 at 4:00AM EDT by NWS Detroit/Pontiac MI
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Detroit/Pontiac has issued a
Coastal Flood Watch, which is in effect from Sunday afternoon
through late Sunday night.

* Coastal Flooding...Northeast gales will develop on southern Lake
Huron and Saginaw Bay Sunday afternoon and will persist through
Sunday night. These winds and already high lake levels will
result in the potential for flooding along the lakeshore of
Saginaw Bay.

* Impacts...The combination of rising water and wave action may
lead to considerable beach erosion and damage to structures
along Saginaw Bay.
properties.instruction:
A Coastal Flood Watch means that conditions favorable for
flooding are expected to develop. Coastal residents should be
alert for later statements or warnings...and take action to
protect property.

* Prepare, plan and stay informed. Visit
www.weather.gov/safety/flood

To learn more about dangerous waves and currents please visit
dangerouscurrents.org

NWSheadline: COASTAL FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT FROM SUNDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH LATE SUNDAY NIGHT

properties.headline: Coastal Flood Watch issued April 13 at 1:12PM EDT until April 14 at 4:00PM EDT by NWS Detroit/Pontiac MI
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Detroit/Pontiac has issued a
Coastal Flood Watch, which is in effect from Sunday morning
through Sunday afternoon.

* Coastal Flooding...Strong easterly winds are expected to develop
on Lake Erie Sunday morning. This will cause lake levels to rise
across the western basin of the lake. This along with the
potential for moderate rain may lead to some flooding in
Gibraltar. Gusty northeast winds are also expected on Lake St
Clair. Winds will weaken and back toward the north Sunday
afternoon which will allow lake levels to decrease.

* Impacts...Some flooding is possible in and around Gibraltar.
There may also be some erosion and minor flooding along the
shoreline of Lake St Clair in the Grosse Pointes.
properties.instruction:
A Coastal Flood Watch means that conditions favorable for
flooding are expected to develop. Coastal residents should be
alert for later statements or warnings...and take action to
protect property.

properties.headline: Coastal Flood Watch issued April 13 at 1:12PM EDT until April 15 at 12:00PM EDT by NWS Detroit/Pontiac MI
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Detroit/Pontiac has issued a
Coastal Flood Watch, which is in effect from Sunday afternoon
through Monday morning.

* Coastal Flooding...North to northeast gales will develop on
southern Lake Huron Sunday afternoon and will persist into
Monday morning. These winds and already high lake levels will
result in the potential for flooding along the Lake Huron
lakeshore.

* Impacts...The combination of rising water and wave action may
lead to considerable beach erosion. There is also the potential
for damage to structures that are at lake level near the shore.
properties.instruction:
A Coastal Flood Watch means that conditions favorable for
flooding are expected to develop. Coastal residents should be
alert for later statements or warnings...and take action to
protect property.

NWSheadline: COASTAL FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT FROM SUNDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH MONDAY MORNING

properties.headline: Coastal Flood Watch issued April 13 at 1:12PM EDT until April 14 at 4:00PM EDT by NWS Detroit/Pontiac MI
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Detroit/Pontiac has issued a
Coastal Flood Watch, which is in effect from Sunday morning
through Sunday afternoon.

* Coastal Flooding...Strong east-northeast winds are expected to
develop on Lake Erie Sunday morning. This will cause lake levels
to rise across the western basin of Lake Erie, possibly
exceeding 72 inches. The winds will back toward the north and
are expected to weaken Sunday afternoon, which will allow lake
levels to drop.

* Impacts...The combination of rising lake levels and wave action
will pose the potential for flooding and property damage along
the Lake Erie shoreline. With the winds forecast to be a little
more northeast, the highest lake levels are expected to impact
locations around Luna Pier south to Maumee Bay.

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued April 13 at 1:04PM EDT until April 13 at 11:20PM EDT by NWS State College PA
properties.description:
Swatara Creek At Harper Tavern
The National Weather Service in State College, PA has issued a

* Flood Warning for
The Swatara Creek At Harper Tavern
* until this evening...Or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 1 PM Saturday the stage was...8.9 feet.
* Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* The river is forecast to rise above flood stage by this afternoon
and crest near 9.1 feet by late this afternoon.  The river will
fall below flood stage by late this afternoon.
* At 9.0 feet...Several driveways and other minor roadways are
affected. Water begins to enter some basements.
properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety message...Never drive cars through flooded areas!! The water
may be too deep to allow safe passage. Most deaths that occur during
flooding are related to vehicles trying to cross flooded roadways.

An update to this product will be issued laster this evening.

properties.areaDesc: Escambia Coastal; Baldwin Coastal; Santa Rosa Coastal; Mobile Coastal; Okaloosa Coastal
properties.headline: High Surf Advisory issued April 13 at 12:04PM CDT until April 15 at 5:00AM CDT by NWS Mobile AL
properties.description:
* WAVES AND SURF...Surf height building up to 5 to 8 feet this
afternoon through Sunday. High risk of rip currents continues
through Sunday night.

* TIMING...Through Sunday night.

* WHERE...The beaches of Alabama and the Northwest Florida
Panhandle.

* IMPACTS...Frequent life-threatening rip currents are expected.
The surf is dangerous for all levels of swimmers.
properties.instruction:
A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in
the advisory area, producing localized beach erosion and
dangerous swimming conditions.

There is a high risk of rip currents. Rip currents are life-
threatening to anyone entering the surf. Swim near a lifeguard. If
caught in a rip current remain calm. Don't fight the current.
Swim in a direction following the shoreline. If unable to escape,
face the shore and call or wave for help. If tired, float or tread
water until out of the rip current.

properties.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued April 13 at 1:00PM EDT until April 13 at 3:45PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
properties.description:
At 1251 PM EDT, earlier reports from emergency management indicate
that there were numerous issues across Concord and Kannapolis due
to flooding.  Residents of an apartment complex had to be evacuated
due to ground-level flooding and other residents reported water
approaching the ground-level of their homes.  Several roads have
been impacted as well.

Doppler radar shows that the heavy rainfall has ended across NW
Cabarrus County and additional rainfall is not expected through
mid-afternoon.  However, ongoing flooding issues persist and the
Flash Flood Warning will be allowed to continue until
confirmation is received that the floodwaters have receded.

Some locations that are continuing to experience flooding
include...Kannapolis, Downtown Concord, West Concord, Charlotte
Motor Speedway, Coddle Creek Reservoir and Harrisburg.
properties.instruction:
Excessive runoff from heavy rainfall will cause flooding in urban
areas. Storm drains, streams and other drainages will become
overwhelmed by excessive rainfall, flooding low-lying roads,
intersections, and parking lots. Underpasses are especially dangerous
because sudden flood waters can quickly surround and submerge your
vehicle. Stay alert and avoid flood-prone areas.

Numerous roads, parking lots and bridges will be threatened by heavy
rain and rapidly rising streams and creeks. Please pay close
attention to road signs indicating a flood-prone area. Obey all
barricades, even if water is not currently over the road. Barricades
are in place for your protection and indicate areas where flooding
can occur rapidly and without warning.

When it is safe to do so, please report flood waters or landslides
flowing over roads or threatening property to the National Weather
Service by calling toll free, 1, 800, 2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, by posting on
our Facebook page, or via Twitter using hashtag NWSGSP. Your message
should describe the event and the specific location where it
occurred, including roadways, nearby cross streets, stream names and
other landmarks.

properties.description:
At 1255 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm over
Pickens, moving east at 20 mph.

Locations to be impacted include...
Pickens, Berea, Travelers Rest, Slater-Marietta, Paris Mountain State
Park, Cherrydale Point, Furman University, Pleasant Ridge State Park,
Pumpkintown and Dacusville.

Wind gusts up to 50 mph and nickel size hail will be possible in
these areas.
properties.instruction:
Gusty winds can blow down trees that are dead, or that have weakened
root systems. Outdoor furniture and similar items can be tossed
around if not anchored. Seek shelter indoors.

Dime to nickel size hail can cause considerable damage to vehicles.
Consider moving vehicles to a covered storage area before the storm
arrives.

Pea size hail and wind gusts up to 40 mph will be possible with this
storm.

Heavy rain and minor flooding will also be possible with this storm.

Locations impacted include...
Pittsboro, Siler City, Goldston, Bynum, Moncure, Hasty and Lake
Jordan.
properties.instruction:
Seek shelter in a nearby building or vehicle. Wind gusts as high as
40 mph are capable of knocking down tree limbs and blowing around
trash cans, and other light outdoor objects.

Locally heavy rain will quickly reduce visibility and result in
ponding of water on roadways, standing water in low lying areas, and
minor flooding of creeks, streams, and areas of poor drainage.
Drivers are urged to slow down and use extra caution to avoid
hydroplaning, especially in urban areas where prolonged heavy rain
can quickly lead to flooding.

across South Texas providing strong and gusty west winds this
afternoon and early evening across the Brush Country.

* IMPACTS...Will make driving high profile vehicles difficult.
Outdoor furniture can be blown around.
properties.instruction:

or wind gusts around 40 mph or greater are expected. Winds this
strong can make driving difficult...especially for high profile
vehicles. Use extra caution.

properties.headline: Red Flag Warning issued April 13 at 11:52AM CDT until April 13 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Corpus Christi TX
properties.description:
An intense low pressure system will develop over west Texas and
move rapidly east across the Southern Plains today. Gusty west to
northwest winds are forecast behind this system this afternoon
and early evening. These winds combined with very low relative
humidities will bring critical fire weather conditions to the
area.
* AFFECTED AREA...Duval...La Salle...McMullen...Webb.

* TIMING...From 1 PM CDT Saturday through 7 PM CDT Saturday.

* WIND...West to northwest 20 to 30 mph gusts to 40 mph.

* HUMIDITY...Falling to between 10 and 20 percent over the Rio
Grande Plains and Brush Country.

* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly.
Outdoor burning is not recommended.
properties.instruction:
A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions
are either occurring now....or will shortly. A combination of
strong winds...low relative humidity...and warm temperatures can
contribute to extreme fire behavior. Residents are urged to
exercise care with respect to all outdoor activities that could
inadvertently cause wildfires. Report wildfires quickly to the
nearest fire department or law enforcement office.

NWSheadline: RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 PM CDT THIS EVENING FOR DRY AND WINDY CONDITIONS FOR THE RIO GRANDE PLAINS

properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued April 13 at 11:43AM CDT by NWS Brownsville TX
properties.description:
At 1139 AM CDT, Satellite imagery and surface observations are
tracking a strong but dry cold front moving into the northwestern
sections of Deep South Texas. This dry cold front is located along a
line extending from 6 miles west of Rosita to near Bruni to 12 miles
northwest of Las Palmas. Movement was southeast at 45 mph.

Brief wind gusts from 40 to 50 mph will be possible as this dry cold
front moves quickly southeast.

Locations impacted include...
Zapata, Rio Grande City, Roma, Falfurrias, Sullivan City, Escobares,
Encino, El Sauz, Garciasville and Los Ebanos.

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued April 13 at 11:40AM CDT by NWS Lake Charles LA
properties.description:
Calcasieu River Near Oakdale

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Louisiana...

Calcasieu River Near Oberlin
Calcasieu River At Old Town Bay
Atchafalaya River At Morgan City
Calcasieu River Near Glenmora

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in

Sabine River Near Deweyville
The Flood Warning continues for
The Calcasieu River Near Glenmora.
* until further notice...or until the warning is cancelled.
* At 10:45 AM Saturday the stage was 14.1 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 12.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 14.4 feet by
Tuesday morning then begin falling.
* Impact...At stages near 15.0 feet...Flooding of secondary roads
near the river and its tributaries begins, including Ashmore Road.
Strothers Crossing Road near Calcasieu and Price Crossing Road near
Hineston have several feet of water over them and subject to
washouts.
* Impact...At stages near 14.0 feet...Some roads upstream from
Glenmora, including Strothers Crossing Road near the community of
Calcasieu and Price Crossing Road near Hineston have two to three
feet of water over the road and are subject to being closed.
Flooding of forested areas near the river will also occur.
* Impact...At stages near 12.0 feet...When the river is rising and
the gauge reading is forecast to reach 12 feet or higher. Roads
upstream from Glenmora, including Strothers Crossing Road near the
community of Calcasieu and Price Crossing Road near Hineston have
water on them and are subject to being closed. Also, flooding of
forested areas near the river will occur.
* Impact...At stages near 12.0 feet...When the river is falling and
the gauge reading is forecast to be near 12 feet, flooding of
forested areas near the river will occur.

Granville County in central North Carolina...
Northeastern Wake County in central North Carolina...
Franklin County in central North Carolina...

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...

properties.instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Do not
drive your vehicle into areas where the water covers the roadway.
The water depth may be too great to allow your car to cross safely.
Move to higher ground.

It is important to know where you are relative to streams, rivers,
or creeks which can become killers in heavy rains. Campers and
hikers should avoid streams or creeks.

properties.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued April 13 at 12:38PM EDT until April 13 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Raleigh NC
properties.description:
At 1234 PM EDT, emergency management reported flash flooding across
portions of Davidson and Randolph counties. Flash flooding is
already occurring, and likely to worsen as precip continues to fall.
Some locations experiencing flooding include Thomasville and Denton.
Numerous roads have been closed due to high water. Use caution
especially if traveling in these areas.

Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Greensboro, High Point, Asheboro, Lexington, Randleman, North
Carolina Zoo, Thomasville, Linwood, Archdale and Trinity.
properties.instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

Excessive runoff from the heavy rain will cause flash flooding of
creeks and streams, roads, low lying and poor drainage areas. Do not
drive your vehicle into areas where water covers the road. Many roads
and intersections in the area will quickly flood. When encountering
flooded roads, turn around, don't drown.

Do not enter or cross flowing water or water of unknown depth.

* Locations impacted include...

properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued April 13 at 12:37PM EDT until April 13 at 6:30PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued a

* Flood Advisory for...
Northwestern Mecklenburg County in the Piedmont of North
Carolina...
Eastern Gaston County in the Piedmont of North Carolina...

* Until 630 PM EDT.

* At 1230 PM EDT, heavy rainfall of 1-2.5 inches from earlier this
morning has caused significant runoff across eastern Gaston and
northwest Mecklenburg County, including the urban areas of Mt.
Holly and Huntersville.  This runoff is still causing significant
stream response and streamgauges across the area suggest bankfull
conditions are occurring.

* Minor flooding of adjacent low-lying areas next to streams
including parks, greenways, farmland, and common-access areas
is likely over the next several hours.  A few roadways may be
impacted as well, prompting some road closures. Drivers are urged
to avoid flooded roadways and obey all barricades, even if water
is not currently over the road. People near streams are urged to
seek higher ground and avoid adjacent areas until the high flows
have subsided.

* The following gauged streams are reaching or exceeding bankfull
stages: Long Creek, McDowell Creek, Torrence Creek, and West
Branch of the Rocky River.

* Some locations that may continue to experience flooding include...
Uptown Charlotte, Huntersville, Central Charlotte, Northeast
Charlotte, Northwest Charlotte, Cornelius, Mt Holly, Davidson,
Belmont and Cramerton.
properties.instruction:
Heavy rainfall will cause ponding of water in urban areas, streets
and underpasses, as well as other poor drainage areas and low lying
spots. Rapid rises on small creeks and streams will also occur,
possibly flooding low water crossings and farmland. Do not attempt to
travel across flooded roads. Turn around, dont drown.

Only when it is safe to do so, please report floodwaters or
landslides flowing over roads or threatening property to the National
Weather Service by calling toll-free, 1, 800, 2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, by
posting on our Facebook page, or via Twitter using hashtag NWSGSP.
Your message should describe the event and the specific location
where it occurred, including roadways, nearby cross streets, stream
names, and other landmarks.

to a safe level.

the banks may be unstable and could collapse.

properties.description:

.Runoff from heavy rainfall expected over the next 24 hours will
cause the Ohio River at Cairo to begin to rise again. The river
is forecast to crest near 45.1 feet Friday. Flooding will continue
until further notice. Further adjustments are possible based on
how much rain actually falls. Check back often for updates.
The Flood Warning continues for
the Ohio River at Cairo.
* until further notice.

Friday morning then begin falling.
properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

SAFETY MESSAGE...

Never drive cars...trucks or sport utility vehicles through flooded
areas. The water may be too deep to allow safe passage. Never allow
children to play in or near flood waters. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio or your local media for further statements and possible updated
forecasts.

Additional information is available at
http://www.crh.noaa.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=pah /lower case/

properties.headline: Tornado Warning issued April 13 at 11:30AM CDT until April 13 at 12:00PM CDT by NWS Fort Worth TX
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Fort Worth has issued a

* Tornado Warning for...
Southeastern Robertson County in central Texas...

* Until noon CDT.

* At 1130 AM CDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing a
tornado was located 9 miles east of Hearne, moving northeast at 35
mph.

HAZARD...Tornado and half dollar size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated rotation.

IMPACT...Flying debris will be dangerous to those caught without
shelter. Mobile homes will be damaged or destroyed.
Damage to roofs, windows, and vehicles will occur.  Tree
damage is likely.

* This tornadic thunderstorm will remain over mainly rural areas of
southeastern Robertson County.
properties.instruction:
TAKE COVER NOW! Move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
sturdy building. Avoid windows. If you are outdoors, in a mobile
home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter and
protect yourself from flying debris.

Heavy rainfall may hide this tornado. Do not wait to see or hear the
tornado. TAKE COVER NOW!

CMAMtext: Tornado Warning in this area til 12:00 PM CDT. Take shelter now. Check local media. -NWS

begin to merge. Honey Island Swamp trails will be under water as
inundation of the swamp begins.

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued April 13 at 11:21AM CDT by NWS New Orleans LA
properties.description:
Mississippi River At Baton Rouge affecting East Baton Rouge and West
Baton Rouge Parishes

Mississippi River At Donaldsonville affecting Ascension Parish
Mississippi River At Reserve affecting St. Charles...St. James and

Mississippi River At Red River Landing affecting East Baton

The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River At Red River Landing.
* Until further notice.
* At 10:00 AM Saturday the stage was 57.3 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 48.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to a stage of 57.1 feet
by Sunday April 14.
* Impact...At 54.0 feet...All river islands along the reach from Red
River Landing to Baton Rouge will be inundated. Recreational camps
and river bottom land will be under water. Water approaches Angola
farm land.
* Impact...At 51.0 feet...All river islands along the reach from Red
River Landing to Baton Rouge will be inundated. Recreational camps
and river bottom farm land will be under water.
* Impact...At 48.0 feet...Access roads will be inundated and
evacuation of all river islands must be complete. Protection of
people and property in the river bottom land on the river side of
the levees must be complete.
* Impact...At 46.0 feet...River traffic will become dangerous. A levee
crevasse would flood adjacent farm land. Significant flooding of
Raccourci Island will continue and evacuation of the island is
recommended.
* Impact...At 45.0 feet...Between the 40 and 45 foot stage flooding of
Raccourci Island becomes significant. At the 45 foot stage
evacuation of the island is recommended.

properties.areaDesc: Orange, NC; Alamance, NC; Durham, NC
properties.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued April 13 at 12:20PM EDT until April 13 at 3:15PM EDT by NWS Raleigh NC
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Raleigh has issued a

* Flash Flood Warning for...
Alamance County in central North Carolina...
Orange County in central North Carolina...
Durham County in central North Carolina...

* Until 315 PM EDT

* At 1218 PM EDT, emergency management officials reported heavy rain
across the warned area has led to extensive flooding on area
roadways across Orange County. Up to two inches of rain have
already fallen with additional rainfall amounts of up to two
inches possible. Flash flooding is already occurring and likely to
worsen over the next several hours. Use caution, especially if
traveling in these areas.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Durham, Chapel Hill, Burlington, Graham, Hillsborough, Carrboro,
Mebane, Elon College, Rougemont and Gibsonville.
properties.instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

Excessive runoff from the heavy rain will cause flash flooding of
creeks and streams, roads, low lying and poor drainage areas. Do not
drive your vehicle into areas where water covers the road. Many roads
and intersections in the area will quickly flood. When encountering
flooded roads, turn around, don't drown.

CMAMtext: Flash Flood Warning this area til 3:15 PM EDT. Avoid flood areas. -NWS

properties.headline: Tornado Warning issued April 13 at 11:17AM CDT until April 13 at 12:00PM CDT by NWS Fort Worth TX
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Fort Worth has issued a

* Tornado Warning for...
Northeastern and eastern Robertson County in central Texas...

* Until noon CDT.

* At 1116 AM CDT, a confirmed large and extremely dangerous tornado
was located near Franklin, or 9 miles north of Hearne, moving
northeast at 30 mph.

This is a PARTICULARLY DANGEROUS SITUATION. TAKE COVER NOW!

HAZARD...Damaging tornado.

SOURCE...Radar confirmed tornado.

IMPACT...You are in a life-threatening situation. Flying debris
may be deadly to those caught without shelter. Mobile
homes will be destroyed. Considerable damage to homes,
businesses, and vehicles is likely and complete
destruction is possible.

* Locations impacted include...
Franklin.
properties.instruction:
To repeat, a large, extremely dangerous and potentially deadly
tornado is on the ground. To protect your life, TAKE COVER NOW! Move
to an interior room on the lowest floor of a sturdy building. Avoid
windows. If you are outdoors, in a mobile home, or in a vehicle, move
to the closest substantial shelter and protect yourself from flying
debris.

Heavy rainfall may hide this tornado. Do not wait to see or hear the
tornado. TAKE COVER NOW!

CMAMtext: Tornado Warning in this area til 12:00 PM CDT. Take shelter now. Check local media. -NWS

properties.headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued April 13 at 11:16AM CDT until April 13 at 12:00PM CDT by NWS Fort Worth TX
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Fort Worth has issued a

* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...
Hopkins County in north central Texas...

* Until noon CDT.

* At 1115 AM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near Pleasant
Grove, or 11 miles west of Winnsboro, moving north at 30 mph. This
storm produced hail in Mineola around 1045 AM.

HAZARD...Quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Damage to vehicles is possible.

* Locations impacted include...
Sulphur Springs, Como, Cooper Lake Park South Sulphur and Tira.

This includes Interstate 30 between mile markers 120 and 142.
properties.instruction:
For your protection get inside a sturdy structure and stay away from
windows.

This storm has a history of producing large hail. SEEK SHELTER NOW
inside a sturdy structure and stay away from windows!

Heavy rainfall is occurring with this storm, and may lead to flash
flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded roadways.

properties.areaDesc: S of Cape Lookout NC to Surf City NC out to 20 nm; S of Ocracoke Inlet NC to Cape Lookout NC out to 20 nm
properties.headline: Small Craft Advisory issued April 13 at 12:16PM EDT until April 13 at 4:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
properties.description:
Breezy southerly winds will gradually weaken through the day
today. Accordingly, medium period southerly swell will gradually
subside, with seas falling below 6 ft across the coastal waters
by late this afternoon.
* WINDS...South 10 to 15 kt.

* SEAS...4 to 6 feet.
properties.instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 25 to 33 knots
and/or seas of 6 feet or greater are expected to produce
hazardous wave conditions to small craft. Inexperienced mariners,
especially those operating smaller vessels should avoid
navigating in these conditions.

NWSheadline: SMALL CRAFT ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 PM EDT THIS AFTERNOON

properties.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued April 13 at 11:11AM CDT until April 13 at 1:45PM CDT by NWS Shreveport LA
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Shreveport has issued a

* Flash Flood Warning for...
Northwestern De Soto Parish in northwestern Louisiana...
Caddo Parish in northwestern Louisiana...
Southern Bossier Parish in northwestern Louisiana...

* Until 145 PM CDT.

* At 1110 AM CDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing
heavy rain across the warned area. Flash flooding is expected to
begin shortly.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Shreveport, Bossier City, Haughton, Greenwood, Blanchard, Benton,
Stonewall, Mooringsport, Eastwood, Fosters, Keachi, Ferguson,
Curtis, Spring Ridge, Fillmore, Cross Lake, Bodcau, Koran, Ninock
and Kickapoo.
properties.instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

CMAMtext: Flash Flood Warning this area til 1:45 PM CDT. Avoid flood areas. -NWS

properties.areaDesc: Williamson; Gonzales; Caldwell; Bastrop; Lee; Travis; Fayette; Hays
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued April 13 at 11:11AM CDT by NWS Austin/San Antonio TX
properties.description:
At 1111 AM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking strong thunderstorms along
a line extending from near Salado to near San Marcos. Movement was
east at 45 mph.

Half inch hail and wind gusts up to 50 mph will be possible with
these storms.

Locations impacted include...
Austin, Round Rock, Cedar Park, Georgetown, San Marcos, Pflugerville,
Kyle, Taylor, Buda, Lockhart, Elgin, Bastrop, Giddings, Smithville,
Granger, Lexington, Serenada, Anderson Mill, Windemere and Tanglewood
Forest.

A Severe Thunderstorm Watch remains in effect until 300 PM CDT for
south central Texas.

NWSheadline: SIGNIFICANT WEATHER ADVISORY FOR WILLIAMSON...CALDWELL...EAST CENTRAL HAYS...TRAVIS...BASTROP...LEE...NORTH CENTRAL GONZALES AND WESTERN FAYETTE COUNTIES UNTIL 1215 PM CDT

properties.headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued April 13 at 11:06AM CDT until April 13 at 11:45AM CDT by NWS Austin/San Antonio TX
properties.description:
At 1105 AM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located over Jourdanton,
moving east at 40 mph.

HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.

SOURCE...Radar indicated.

IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage to
roofs, siding, and trees.

Locations impacted include...
Pleasanton, Jourdanton, Charlotte, Christine, Coughran, Dobrowolski,
McCoy, Davis and Hindes.
properties.instruction:
For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a
building.

Prepare immediately for large hail and damaging winds. People outside
should move to a shelter, inside a strong building and away from
windows.

NWSheadline: A SEVERE THUNDERSTORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 1145 AM CDT FOR CENTRAL ATASCOSA COUNTY

properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued April 13 at 11:06AM CDT until April 13 at 2:00PM CDT by NWS Fort Worth TX
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Fort Worth has issued a

* Flood Advisory for Minor Flooding in Poor Drainage Areas for...
Ellis County in north central Texas...
Dallas County in north central Texas...

* Until 200 PM CDT.

* At 1105 AM CDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms that were
producing heavy rainfall across Dallas and Ellis counties.
Excessive runoff from these thunderstorms will cause minor
flooding. Areas that are low lying or usually experience poor
drainage are most likely to experience flooding. This means some
low water crossings in the region may become impassable. Up to one
inch of rain has already fallen and another 1 to 2 inches is
possible through 200 pm.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Dallas, Garland, Irving, Grand Prairie, Mesquite, Carrollton,
Richardson, Mansfield, Rowlett, Desoto, Grapevine, Cedar Hill,
Wylie, Coppell, Duncanville, Lancaster, Waxahachie, Farmers Branch,
Balch Springs and University Park.
properties.instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

properties.headline: The Tornado Warning has been cancelled.
properties.description: The Tornado Warning has been cancelled and is no longer in effect.

NWSheadline: THE TORNADO WARNING FOR EAST CENTRAL MILAM COUNTY IS CANCELLED

properties.headline: Tornado Warning issued April 13 at 11:04AM CDT until April 13 at 11:30AM CDT by NWS Fort Worth TX
properties.description:
At 1103 AM CDT, a confirmed large and extremely dangerous tornado was
located near Calvert, or near Hearne, moving northeast at 30 mph.

This is a PARTICULARLY DANGEROUS SITUATION. TAKE COVER NOW!

HAZARD...Damaging tornado.

SOURCE...Radar confirmed tornado.

IMPACT...You are in a life-threatening situation. Flying debris may
be deadly to those caught without shelter. Mobile homes
will be destroyed. Considerable damage to homes,
businesses, and vehicles is likely and complete destruction
is possible.

Locations impacted include...
Hearne, Franklin and Calvert.
properties.instruction:
To repeat, a large, extremely dangerous and potentially deadly
tornado is on the ground. To protect your life, TAKE COVER NOW! If
you are outdoors, in a mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the
closest substantial shelter now!  Get to an interior room on the
lowest floor of a sturdy building and avoid windows.

Heavy rainfall may hide this tornado. Do not wait to see or hear the
tornado. TAKE COVER NOW!

NWSheadline: A TORNADO WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 1130 AM CDT FOR CENTRAL ROBERTSON COUNTY

properties.areaDesc: Dickens, TX; Cottle, TX; King, TX; Kent, TX; Crosby, TX; Motley, TX
properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued April 13 at 11:00AM CDT until April 13 at 11:30AM CDT by NWS Lubbock TX
properties.description:
At 1054 AM CDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated
widespread light to moderate rain falling on spots that have already
received heavy rainfall. This will cause minor flooding to continue
in the advisory area. 1.50 to 2.50 inches of rain have already
fallen in this area. The West Texas Mesonet has recorded rain totals
of 2.49 inches near Guthrie, 2.44 inches near Paducah, 2.31 inches
at Jayton, and 2.29 inches at White River Lake.

Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Crosbyton, Spur, Paducah, Matador, Jayton, Dickens, Guthrie, White
River Lake, Lake Alan Henry, Kalgary, Girard, Cee Vee, Afton,
Clairemont, Swearingen, Grow, Dumont, Finney, Delwin and Chalk.

Additional rainfall rates of a tenth to quarter inch an hour will be
possible through early afternoon.  This additional rain, on top
of what has already fallen, will result in minor flooding.
properties.instruction:
Excessive runoff from moderate to heavy rainfall will cause flooding
of small creeks and streams, country roads, farmland, and other low
lying spots.

NWSheadline: THE FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 1130 AM CDT FOR KENT... DICKENS...WESTERN KING...SOUTHEASTERN CROSBY...EASTERN MOTLEY AND COTTLE COUNTIES

closest substantial shelter now!  Get to an interior room on the
lowest floor of a sturdy building and avoid windows.

Heavy rainfall may hide this tornado. Do not wait to see or hear the
tornado. TAKE COVER NOW!

conditions or forecasts change.

through flooded areas.  The water may be too deep to allow for safe
passage.

is available at http://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=lsx.
